total_impedance_txt: R4 and R2 connected in series so Rd=R4+R2=9Ohm
R5 and Rd connected in parallel so Rc=R5*Rd/(R5+Rd)=1.64Ohm
R3 and Rc connected in series so Rb=R3+Rc=4.64Ohm
Rb and R1 connected in series so Ra=Rb+R1=5.64Ohm

request.text: What is the current on R5?

solution: *** Solution by TINA assisted by AI ***
At first we calculate the total resistance between the generator nodes (VS1)
R4 and R2 connected in series so Rd=R4+R2=9Ohm
R5 and Rd connected in parallel so Rc=R5*Rd/(R5+Rd)=1.64Ohm
R3 and Rc connected in series so Rb=R3+Rc=4.64Ohm
Rb and R1 connected in series so Ra=Rb+R1=5.64Ohm
The total resistance is Ra = 5.64Ohm
Now we calculate the current on R5
We know that the voltage between VS1 nodes is 6V.
(1) The components Rb,R1 connected in series.
(1) The voltage between this components starting and ending node is 6V.
(1) Rb is in the voltage divider so the voltage on Rb is Rb/Ra*6V = 4.94V.
(1) The current on Rb is the 'voltage on Rb / Rb' = 1.06A .
(2) The components R3,Rc connected in series.
(2) The voltage between this components starting and ending node is 4.94V.
(2) Rc is in the voltage divider so the voltage on Rc is Rc/Rb*4.94V = 1.74V.
(2) The current on Rc is the 'voltage on Rc / Rc' = 1.06A .
(3) The components R5,Rd connected in parallel. The voltage on R5 is 1.74V because the voltage on Rc is 1.74V
(3) The current on R5 is the 'voltage on R5 / R5' = 871mA .
*** Passed ***: expected: -870m, got: -871m
